awd_titl_txt: CIF: Small: Signal Processing for Quanta Image Sensors: Reconstruction, Sampling, and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The proliferation of digital cameras over the past decades has revolutionized almost every aspect of science, technology and society. However, as we continue to shrink image sensors to increase spatial resolution and reduce camera size, the size of the photon-collecting site of a sensor will soon reach a fundamental limit below which no meaningful signal can be generated. The goal of this research is to investigate a new type of image sensor called the Quanta Image Sensors (QIS). Compared to conventional image sensors, QIS offer substantially higher spatial resolution, temporal resolution, and dynamic range. Because of these important features, the sensor has the potential to impact a wide range of applications in digital cameras, consumer electronics, wearable devices, medical imaging, and physical science. 

The focus of the research is to develop signal processing theories and algorithms to support QIS. Building upon previous studies in QIS, this research puts extra emphasis on bridging the theories to practice. Specific questions addressed include: (1) Image reconstruction. How to reconstruct images from the massive binary bit-stream collected by the QIS without using iterative algorithms? (2) Sampling. How to control the sensor?s sampling mechanism in spatial-temporal resolution, color space, and threshold to maximize the signal to noise ratio? (3) Application. How to track fast moving objects using QIS without reconstructing images? Results from this research will foster new signal processing techniques for imaging in photon limited environments.

Project Summary.

The proliferation of digital cameras over the past decades has revolutionized almost every aspect of science, technology, and society. However, as we continue to shrink image sensors to increase spatial resolution and reduce camera size, image sensors will soon reach two fundamental limits: (i) the reduced photon detection area of the sensors, and (ii) the reduced number of photoelectrons that can be stored in the sensors, also known as the full-well capacity. As image sensors approach these two limits, the signal-to-noise ratio and dynamic range of an image will drop below a critical level, eventually making the images useless.

Quanta image sensor (QIS) is a class of single-photon image sensors that are envisioned to succeed CCD and CMOS as the next generation image sensor. Equipped with signal processing algorithms, the sensor is able to produce images with high spatial resolution, high temporal speed, and high dynamic range. However, past research on QIS was mainly driven by circuit design and fabrication. Signal processing methods, although available, are largely in a proof-of-concept stage. Important questions in practical situations, e.g., real-time image reconstruction, optimal sampling mechanism, and high-speed imaging configurations, remain unanswered. Unless these critical issues are properly addressed, the prospect of QIS will be significantly diminished due to our inability to sample and reconstruct image signals efficiently from the sensor. This presents a pressing need to elevate signal processing theories and algorithms of QIS from the existing proof-of-concept stage to a practical stage.

The NSF-funded research project #1718007: CIF: Small: Signal Processing for Quanta Image Sensors: Reconstruction, Sampling, and Applications is positioned as a set of non-traditional signal processing theories and algorithms for a new type of image sensor. 

Intellectual Merit

The intellectual merit of the project is summarized by the three accomplished objectives. 

Intellectual Merit 1: Fast Image Reconstruction. Several image reconstruction algorithms for QIS are developed. These algorithms include (1) a non-iterative transform-denoise framework that produces images at low computational cost; (2) multiple deep neural network-based algorithms that achieve state-of-the-art image reconstruction quality; (3) color image reconstruction algorithms and color filter array designs to improve the color fidelity of the images. 

Intellectual Merit 2: Optimal Sampling to Maximize Signal-to-Noise. New theories are developed to explain how the SNR is affected by the threshold and how to optimize the threshold. New theoretical results are established to characterize the sensor?s performance for high-dynamic-range imaging, including a new algorithm for optimal linear combination. 

Intellectual Merit 3: High-Speed Applications. A fast image classification algorithm and a new object detection algorithm at extreme low-light conditions are developed. To support these two new algorithms, a new student-teacher learning scheme is built to regularize the deep-neural networks. Theory of the student-teacher learning is also developed. 

Broader Impact

The broader impact of the project is summarized in two ways:

Broader Impact 1: Resolving images with single-photon sensitivity is the ultimate goal of scientific imaging. Scientists and engineers are overwhelmingly interested in having new imaging devices that can resolve images with higher resolution, lower noise, and better speed. The image reconstruction techniques developed in this project are important steps toward enabling the QIS technology, with many upcoming applications in surveillance, security, medical imaging, and autonomous vehicles.

Broader Impact 2: On the education front, the funded project supported graduate and undergraduate students' training and career development. One graduate course and one undergraduate course were developed to disseminate the knowledge in computational imaging and machine learning. A pilot high-school outreach project is established to engage with domestic high-school students during the summer by teaching them basic programming tools for machine learning. A new undergraduate textbook Introduction to Probability for Data Science is written during the project period. The book is made free to all students.
